title: Is Safety Standard Same for Everyone? User-Specific Safety Evaluation of Large Language Models
author: Yeonjun In (KAIST), Wonjoong Kim (KAIST), Kanghoon Yoon (KAIST), Sungchul Kim (Adobe Research), Md Mehrab Tanjim (Adobe Research), Kibum Kim (KAIST), Chanyoung Park (KAIST), Chanyoung Park (KAIST)
relevance_why: The user-specific safety considerations introduced in this paper could be instrumental in audio generation models, especially in ensuring that these models avoid generating harmful outputs for specific user contexts.
field: Social and Economic Aspects of ML-Safety
background: Evaluating safety protocols for Large Language Models (LLMs) while considering specific user profiles, rather than relying solely on general safety standards.
contribution: This paper introduces the U-SAFEBENCH framework to assess user-specific safety of LLMs, revealing significant vulnerabilities in current models.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous safety evaluations primarily focused on general safety standards, neglecting individual user circumstances in risk assessment.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work emphasizes user-specific safety, creating a unique benchmark that captures diverse user profiles and potential safety risks.

key_innovation: The introduction of the user-specific safety benchmarking, which evaluates how LLMs might respond differently based on individual user backgrounds.
real_world_impact: This research has the potential to enhance the deployment of LLMs in sensitive applications where user safety is paramount, such as mental health support and legal advice.
limitations: The models evaluated still show inadequate safety performance and may not be ready for real-world deployment.

new_terms.user-specific safety: **User-specific safety** refers to the concept where the safety responses of LLMs are tailored based on individual user profiles, considering their unique contexts and potential vulnerabilities.

open_sourcing: The benchmark and code are available at https://github.com/yeonjun-in/U-SafeBench.
